lines: i am concerned about the six additional antennas put in there, running at 10.1 giga hertz

Amendment of Administrative Code Chapter 31 [Board File No. 061311] - Informational Presentation. Ordinance introduced by Supervisor Ma amending Administrative Code Chapter 31 provisions for appeals of environmental documents and determinations to the Board of Supervisors under the California Environmental Quality Act, as well as public notice of such determinations and environmental documents.
preliminary_recommendation: adopt resolution supporting board adoption of the ordinance, with department-recommended modifications
speakers: sue hestor, robert pender, steve williams, john bardis

speaker_statements.speaker: sue hestor
lines: urges returning to 'intent to approve' resolutions instead of amending on the fly
says delayed resolutions (sometimes weeks) hinder timely appeals
notes appeals require knowing exact approved language and plans, including environmental approvals
tight timelines make it hard to state grounds if project modifications are unknown
recommends starting appeal deadlines only after final project and environmental resolutions are complete, or changing commission practice

speaker_statements.speaker: robert pender
lines: believes the public lacks sufficient opportunity and notice as access is curtailed
calls for greater openness
asks to make procedures more open and accessible to ordinary citizens who live with the results

speaker_statements.speaker: steve williams
lines: states ceqa is the main tool to protect historic resources
says the department often issues categorical exemptions, so an effective appeal process is essential
argues the legislation is bad and appears to make appeals harder for neighbors and the public
criticizes short deadlines (10, 30, 90 days) where previously there were none until permits or project start

speaker_statements.speaker: john bardis
lines: says in city hall the three criteria for legislation are 'process, process, process'
criticizes 'end runs' via the administrative code and plan processes
warns proposed procedural changes effectively take away people’s rights
urges the commission to recognize the broader implications beyond individual cases

ayes: alexander, antonini, olague, lee, moore, sugaya

project_descr: Mandatory Discretionary Review, under the Planning Code Section 890.133(h) requiring review of Medical Cannabis Dispensaries (MCDs), of Building Permit Application 2005.03.29.8691, to maintain operation of an existing MCD (d.b.a. HopeNet Co-Op).
preliminary_recommendation: do not take discretionary review and approve the project as proposed
speakers: wayne justmann, michelle aldrich, richard muller, rose kenyon, john caldera, terrie frye, rev. randi webster, cathy smith, johnny nolen, shona, leslie thomas, robert carlton, tony bowles, michael aldrich, dana blackford, jim meko, bruce allison

speaker_statements.speaker: wayne justmann
lines: says hope net is a good cannabis facility that serves the city and neighborhood well
praises steve and kathy smith and their staff for understanding patients’ needs
urges approval as in the community’s best interest

speaker_statements.speaker: michelle aldrich
lines: speaks in support of hope net, calling it a model dispensary
notes many patients live in section 8 housing and cannot medicate at home
says patients feel safe at hope net and the neighborhood feels safer
asks the commission to vote for it

speaker_statements.speaker: richard muller
lines: met steve and kathy and has visited the facility
before hope net, relied on the patients health defense union
notes many patients were poor and typical club prices were unaffordable

speaker_statements.speaker: rose kenyon
lines: medical cannabis patient living in the area for 40+ years
finds medical marijuana most effective after many prescriptions
says dispensaries are being eliminated despite being established and reputable
notes compassion means free or low-cost medication
recommends adopting staff’s proposal

speaker_statements.speaker: john caldera
lines: u.s. navy veteran and california card-carrying patient living with hiv since 1995
says medical cannabis has helped keep him alive
calls hope net a phenomenal dispensary that serves the community
asks to allow them to continue services

speaker_statements.speaker: terrie frye
lines: grateful to kathy and steve smith and hope net for their priorities and donations
says cannabis let her quit ineffective depression meds
warns she would be depressed if hope net were not permitted to stay open

speaker_statements.speaker: rev. randi webster
lines: calls hope net a model facility for compassion and community awareness
says they care for patients and are open to everyone
urges not to take discretionary review and praises their work

speaker_statements.speaker: cathy smith
lines: owner and operator of hope net seeking community consent to operate
aims to continue the compassion program for the terminally ill
thanks local businesses, community, and the planning commission
says they are community-minded and want to keep operating to help patients

speaker_statements.speaker: johnny nolen
lines: became involved to help patients and protect their rights
impressed by hope net’s services, professionalism, and community awareness
says hope net supports a large compassion program supplying medicine to severely ill patients
notes importance given lack of insurance coverage for medical cannabis

speaker_statements.speaker: shona
speaker_statements.descr: executive director of a patient advocacy organization
lines: says san francisco can be a national model
believes hope net co-op should set the standard due to its compassion program
wants permitted low-impact costs for people on fixed incomes
notes they offer space to the women’s health collective and other groups
supports permitting this compassionate co-op as a national model

speaker_statements.speaker: leslie thomas
lines: medical marijuana patient using hope net on 9th street since opening
feels comfortable due to their efforts to keep the neighborhood clean and safe
says she is treated as a patient, not a customer, with compassion
asks to allow hope net to remain at its current location

speaker_statements.speaker: robert carlton
lines: speaks in support of hope net
has been a patient and associated with them since opening
calls it the most compassionate club in san francisco

speaker_statements.speaker: tony bowles
lines: neighbor and bookstore owner next door to hope net
says problematic activity at the location has decreased since hope net opened
notes patients and supporters have fought to protect the right to obtain medical cannabis
asks to give medical cannabis—and hope net—a chance

speaker_statements.speaker: michael aldrich
lines: says hope net has operated for three years with no complaints and meets new regulations
notes they care for about 100 patients free of charge
mentions the historical building and accessibility investments
says this would be the first dispensary approved by the planning commission

speaker_statements.speaker: dana blackford
lines: sustained a brain injury leading to many difficulties
says cannabis alleviated many stresses
calls it frivolous to close hope net

speaker_statements.speaker: jim meko
lines: contrasts this positive case with a previous divisive dr on a club
urges approval as recommended by staff

speaker_statements.speaker: bruce allison
lines: asks to give hope net a chance
says they run a clean and decent dispensary

action: do not take discretionary review and approved
ayes: alexander, olague, antonini, lee, moore, sugaya

project_descr: Request for Discretionary Review of Building Permit Application No. 2006.06.23.4870, proposing to alter the existing second floor roofline; add a penthouse with roof deck towards the rear of the building.

speaker_statements.speaker: nicole
lines: family has been in san francisco since the 1880s; faced exclusionary housing practices and rebuilt after wwii
chose the home for its peaceful setting
fears losing light, view, and privacy if a third level is built
seeks a compromise so both sides can be happy
suggests building at the front of the house to gain similar area without impacting her view, privacy, light, and space

speaker_statements.speaker: no name
lines: says coming forward was difficult; they are not confrontational

proposed extension adds ~13 feet of vertical elevation

speaker_statements.speaker: jonathan
lines: provided a brief description of the project

speaker_statements.speaker: michael saksteder
lines: likes the neighborhood and tried to be sensitive to everyone’s needs while pursuing a modest project

says late-stage input is significantly delaying the project despite earlier opportunities
believes privacy concerns raised are not an issue
states they are trying to be good neighbors and do the project right

speaker_statements.speaker: bryan eckert
lines: fully supports the proposed project
believes it is an enhancement to the neighborhood

action: continued to november 16, 2006. the public hearing remains open
ayes: alexander, antonini, olague, lee, moore, sugaya
